data.title: Hugh Grant Has More Iconic Characters Than You Do
data.meta_description: From 'Four Weddings and a Funeral' to (you know you've seen it) 'Bridget Jones's Diary' to (you knew it was coming) 'Love Actually,' the British actor walks us through his storied career.
data.text:
Only yesterday on the plane,

I was going through my old notes

section of my phone and I found a whole thing

on reasons not to do Thorpe (laughs)

'Cause I was trying to find a reason not to do a job,

because acting scares me so much.

(bright string music)

Maurice, I was in a very dark place,

actually it wasn't dark because what I'd give up.

I was writing and producing radio commercials

and I was extremely happy doing it.

And I wasn't interested in acting anymore.

Then my agent, who I hadn't spoke to for months

rang and said, Oh, they want to see you

for this Merchant Ivory film.

And I said, no I can't be bothered.

And my brother, who is a banker, very bossy,

who happened to be at home sick that day,

I was living with him, said,

Don't be ridiculous, you gotta go,

you need some money, I'm sick of paying for you.

So he made me sort of get dressed up,

and I went and they were kind enough

to like me, that was the first sort

of propulsion into movies.

I didn't know what to expect,

it came out very well, sometimes say to me,

oh, were you worried about playing a gay role?

And I wasn't at all, never sort of struck me

as that was in any way difficult

or dangerous or controversial.

I remember the Venice Film Festival.

The world premiere of the film,

I'm sitting next to James Wilby,

James Ivory, and Ishmael Merchant in the front row

of the sort of circle and at the end of the film,

the audience really loved it.

And they stood up and they clapped

for a long time, and then the tradition

at Venice is that we the filmmakers stand up

to accept the applause.

What I had forgotten is that my suit was much too tight

and I'd undone it, I'd undone my trousers

quite early in the film, and I'd completely forgot

to do them up, so it did look odd

that at the end of this gay film,

I stand up, and bow solemnly to everyone,

next to my costar with my trousers undone.

(bright string music)

Four Weddings and a Funeral.

I got the script and I thought,

well there must be some mistake,

my agent has sent me a good script.

So I rang him up, and I said,

I think there's been a mistake,

you've sent me a good script.

He did that once before, actually,

with Jerry Maguire, and I said, I think there's a mistake.

And they said, yeah, sorry, that is is a mistake,

that was meant for Tom Cruise (laughs).

With Four Weddings, it was meant for me.

Anyway, it was only an audition, and I went

along and I auditioned among the Muppets.

They were all around me.

I remember thinking, it's going quite well.

The director looks like he likes me,

but the writer really hates me,

that was Richard Curtis, and he admits,

he did hate me, he had a completely different conception

of that part; he'd written it in his own image,

he thought it was him and didn't think

that it should be someone who

he thought might get the girl,

he thought it should be more like him,

more kind of nerdish and glasses, anyway,

he had his arm twisted and I got the part.

The haircut became quite popular, yeah, with some,

I always hated it.

The haircut and the clothes, the clothes

are meant to be terrible,

and the haircut's meant to be terrible.

Shortly before we stopped shooting that film,

one lunchtime, they said, okay, everyone,

all the crew, into this room, we're gonna show you

some cut footage of what we've shot so far.

It was meant to be morale-boosting.

And it played to sepulchral silence.

Nothing has ever been worse except for Rowan's bit,

Rowan's bit got a laugh, but the rest of it

was just abominable, and we all trudged back onto the set,

broken men and women, and we remained in that mood

through finishing the film, through editing it,

through the first look at it,

we just thought wow, we're all gonna have

to go live in Peru, and then they had this screening

in Santa Monica, in Los Angeles, and the audience loved it.

It's very odd, the speech pattern was very much written in,

convoluted syntax, if I were to ask you,

could you possibly ever see your way?

I mean I'm not saying you would, but if you might,

to falling in love with me?

All that stuff, that's Richard writing that stuff.

And Mike Newell who directed that film

wanted it even more messed up, he said, look,

it'll be a disaster if you look smooth.

So you know, mess up the lines,

and break them up, so I did all that.

And then when that film was a success,

possibly subliminally I let it bleed

into other parts which was a big mistake.

(bright string music)

Sense and Sensibility.

Emma Thompson adapted Sense and Sensibility.

She got Ang Lee to direct it,

and they offered me that part.

And I saw the part of Edward Ferrars

and I said, well, he's a bit

of a hesitant in-love Englishman,

I don't think I should do that again.

And they said, no, no, we know

you can do it very differently.

So I said, all right then,

and then I did it exactly the same (laughs)

Ang Lee was, I think it was his first non-Taiwanese film,

he didn't, hadn't mastered yet the art

of how to talk to British, and sensitive, British actors.

I remember doing my first scene with Emma.

And I thought we were marvelous.

And we went up to Ang afterwards,

who's sitting there at the monitor, we said,

What did you think, Ang, what did you think?

And he went, Very boring.

And that was very disheartening.

And he famously said to Kate Winslet

at the end of her first day's shooting,

You will get better.

So he was scary, but very charming.

(bright string music)

Notting Hill, the good will from Four Weddings

was dissappating fast, and Richard wrote

this other film and it was based on something

that actually happened to a friend of his

who was a kind of very un-famous bloke

living in Notting Hill who happened to fall in love

with an extremely, extremely word-famous person

who I'm not allowed to mention, and she with him.

So it was based on that, such an obvious idea

for a film I can't believe it's never been made before.

And it just seemed like it was gonna be dynamite.

And then they managed to persuade the then-biggest star

in the world, Julia Roberts to do it,

and then we managed not to screw it up too badly.

And it was just obviously a mega hit

at that moment, because it's really properly romantic.

And that's the key to his films.

They're called dramatic comedies,

and he actually is funny, the jokes are good,

but what's special is that they are genuinely romantic

because he's a romantic.

Poor old Richard was always in love

and being rejected, all that's real.

Rather than fake, ersatz, kind of Hollywood romance.

(bright string music)

Bridget Jones's Diary, you know,

Daniel Cleaver's quite a sort of West London,

smooth, upper middle class.

I don't know why they came to me.

Maybe she thought I was right for it.

All the way through those fluffy films,

Four Weddings, Notting Hill,

it had amused Richard, his gang, his wife, everyone,

people thought I was that nice, fluffy character.

Because they knew I wasn't,

I was much closer to, for instance, Daniel Cleaver.

So I think it was fun for them to then slop me

into a role that was closer to the real me.

(bright string music)

About a Boy, it's a novel by Nick Hornby,

and a really good one, possibly it's slightly based

on himself, maybe, but I'd been sort of tracking it

for ages, and it was being made

by a different company, and that director didn't want me,

and then it got shifted over to the Whites brothers.

And I met them, and we all got on really well,

and they were making it, actually,

with De Niro's company, and I enjoyed that aspect of it,

I loved hanging out with Bob,

we were going night clubbing with him.

No, I felt very cool doing that.

The boy in About a Boy needed to be someone nerdy,

a loser, someone who's gonna get bullied.

And we found Nick, and he was a great actor,

but he was too good-looking, so we gave him a shit haircut,

terrible clothes, but I see now, the dish has triumphed.

He's a massive star.

Will, in About a Boy, is North London,

he's more demotic, trendy, cool,

you know, the clothes I had then were cool for that period.

It was a great part, and transforming for me,

and what I've now realized, because you might not hear it

or see it, but because I'm doing an accent in that,

I'm really doing a performance that's much further

away from me, it was very releasing

and I'm much better when I'm doing that,

that's what's come home to me in the last five years.

Get away from yourself, and I'm actually better.

When you're being someone else,

moving like them, talking like them,

it takes care of the self-consciousness problem.

(bright string music)

Love Actually?

Well, the premise was really again written

rather like Richard Curtis himself.

So when I read this, I thought,

this is gonna be a huge hit.

But I didn't really to be that same character again,

I would get crucified.

So I said to Richard, can't it just be that guy

from Notting Hill and from Four Weddings?

And he said, no no no no no no, so it was quite different,

you know, much tougher and harder.

I went, right, tougher, harder, yes yes yes.

Then I just did exactly the same character (laughs)

of Four Weddings and Notting Hill.

The dancing scene was a terrible cloud

hanging over the whole production for me.

You know, it's hard enough to dance

if you're English and middle-aged,

even with six pints inside you,

but by yourself, so stone-cold sober,

at seven in the morning, in front of a film crew.

To freak out was going to be misery.

Not only that, but I thought the scene

had the capacity for being the most excruciating scene

ever committed to celluloid.

And there are plenty of people who still think it is.

But equally there are lots of people who seem to love it.

(bright string music)

Cloud Atlas.

[Interviewer] Could you explain the plot of Cloud Atlas?

No, no one could (laughs)

It's kind of slightly about reincarnation, as I recall.

All my people are vile.

Out of the blue, the very cool Wachowskis

wanted me to play five or six parts

in this extraordinary, the biggest,

the most expensive independent film ever made.

I went to meet them to see

if it was some kind of joke on me,

and it didn't seem to be.

And I liked them a lot, so I did it,

and you know, it seemed irresistible

to play a cannibal from the 23rd century.

And then I thought, well, I'm bound to be good at that.

That's cause I'm so fascinating.

And I didn't really think about it too much

until I was suddenly on a mountaintop in Germany,

with my teeth and my makeup, and my tattoos.

And I thought, I have no idea how to do this!

I had one of the Wachowskis saying, come on man,

you look at at him like you wanna fucking eat him,

and I thought, I don't have that face!

Give me a funny lie, I can do that.

Not sure I was very good at the cannibal.

But I was quite good at some of the other parts.

I think all actors like to be evil.

I think because it smells true.

I've got this horrible feeling, now I'm 57,

that we are evil and that our veneer of civilization

and niceness is very, very thin.

So when you're allowed to be your true evil self

it just sort of smells right and feels right,

it's fun to play.

(bright string music)

Florence Foster Jenkins, in Florence Foster Jenkins,

I am half good, half bad,

I'm a marvelously supportive husband

and sort of manager to Meryl Streep,

an increasingly deranged amateur singer.

But you're supposed to think,

and I think people did think,

what's his real motive, does he really love her?

Or is he in it for himself?

And hopefully people, you know, think both simultaneously.

I certainly thought he was both.

Which I think is also very human.

We can be loving, unselfish and deeply narcissistic

and selfish simultaneously, and that is what he was.

Meryl's a very good singer in real life,

and probably that's why she was able to be bad so well.

So she would sing badly

and when she first demonstrated that,

at one of the read-throughs, you know,

I just thought, well that's genius,

and it was incredibly funny, really makes you laugh.

But like all funny things, as you repeat them,

you laugh a little bit less, it's to be expected.

She knew that, and so sometimes

if I was on camera watching her,

and she was off camera, she'd just dial it up,

double it to screw me up, make me laugh.

She was very good at that.

And actors like playing actors,

or people in show business, they think

this will be fascinating, but actually

the world hates actors quite rightly.

The key to that character, funnily enough,

is the same key to the next film I did,

Paddington 2, narcissism, they're all narcissists.

I don't know why I keep getting offered these parts,

but anyway, that's incredibly human,

we're really just obsessed with looking out for ourselves.

It's certainly the key to Bayfield

in Florence Foster Jenkins,

he was a crap actor, the real Bayfield,

or at least very moderate, very mediocre,

and yet dazzled by the limelight.

Just, the limelight, the limelight!

And he had therefore the same disease

as Florence Foster Jenkins,

who was the world's worst singer.

Just wanted to be onstage, Carnegie Hall,

everyone looking at here.

And you meet these people, they are very common in life.

And anyway, that was definitely the curse

of Phoenix Buchanan in Paddington 2.

(bright string music)

Paddington 2.

Paul King who wrote and directed it

likes to tell his story that he wrote a part

of a washed up, narcissistic old actor

called it Hugh, and sent it to me first.

They did actually change the name when they sent it to me,

perhaps out of tact.

But nevertheless, the letter that came

with the script did say, we've written

this narcissistic monster of a washed up actor

and we thought of you.

And it was very difficult to get past that letter.

But you know, it was a funny script,

and I thought, I can do that part.

And that film, Paddington, you know,

isn't there when you're shooting,

because obviously he's created in the computer afterwards.

Instead you have a choice, I had a choice

every time I was doing a scene with the bear,

I could have a stick with the bear's head on the end,

which was actually a very sinister thing,

I didn't even like looking at it.

It looked like a kind of warning to bears,

don't come in to this area,

you would have your head cut off,

or you could have this stand in lady

who was the same height as Paddington,

she was great, but that, I ended up with a stick,

became quite fond of the stick in the end.

We used to have lunch together.

(bright string music)

A Very English Scandal, I was about to do something else,

I was having dinner with Stephen Frears one night,

he said, oh, don't do that, I've got something else.

And he sent me these scripts, and I thought, television?

I don't do television.

But, it was him, and I love him, and we seemed to,

you know, we made a successful film together.

It's a fascinating story,

it's a very interesting part of history,

it's my childhood.

The book was brilliant in that it brought out

the black comedy of the whole thing,

very mischievous, and then the screen writers

are extraordinary, Russell T. Davies,

you know,he's a proper genius.

So I had to say yes.

In the courtroom scenes,

where there's long, long push ins on my face,

no actor really likes it, because you start well,

you think, you know I'm bang in-character here,

as the character dollies in for sixteen blood hours,

you know, after sort of ten seconds,

I'm slipping out of character, I'm getting self-conscious

and by a minute, you know, you think,

what's happened to my jaw, I can't even feel it anymore.

Actors decide to do jobs for various reasons,

but I think the two main ones,

is it a very fascinating and showy role for them,

and the other one is will this thing work?

But I've always been absolutely fixated

on will it also be an entertaining thing,

because if not, then this is a wank,

what's the point of it?

So for me, this one had both, and I thought,

people are definitely going to enjoy this.

Because it's such a weird story,

and it's just sort of tragic, and repulsive,

and yet at the same time, funny.

And equally, this is a great part, you know,

he was a many who I sort of knew the breed.

My mother was at Oxford in the '50s.

And the friends she'd made there used to come

to dinner sometimes when I was a kid

and they were very Jeremy Thorpe,

and very smooth, and charming, and reptilian.

So I knew that breed, and here was the sort

of the epitome of one of those guys.

With all this, you know, just dark secrets

and a weird, sort of nasty narcissistic side,

but also tragedy.

Jeremy Thorphe was never able to be himself.

Never able to love someone in his own way,

which happened to be gay.

And that's deeply tragic, that what's one of his tragedies,

and then his other tragedies are more sort of classic,

Greek, Shakespearean one, which is one event

in his life, gradually brings him down.

Having built himself up with a terrific career

and life, reputation, this thing just destroys him.
